identificationModule.briefTitle: Effectiveness of a Treatment Plan of Neurological Physiotherapy in Conjunction With Ultrasound-guided Ultrasound-guided Dry Needling in Stroke Patients.
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effectiveness of a Treatment Plan of Neurological Physiotherapy in Conjunction With Ultrasound-guided Dry Needling in Stroke Patients.

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The aim of the study is to assess the efficacy of dry needling in stroke patients in combination with intensive neurological physiotherapy.

together with intensive neurological physiotherapy treatment. Randomised and blinded experimental study control group where the sample recruited was 20 patients, who were randomly assigned to a control group.

randomly assigned to a control group, where they received intensive treatment, or to an intervention group, where they received intervention group, where they received ultrasound-guided dry needling of the tibialis anterior and posterior muscles followed by an intensive followed by intensive neurological physiotherapy treatment.

armGroups.label: dry needling treatment
armGroups.description: group that includes a dry needling treatment on the tibialis anterior and posterior muscles.

interventions.name: dry needling
interventions.description: is a physiotherapy treatment for neurological patients and studies the efficacy of dry needling by studying several pre-treatment and post-treatment variables after the experimental treatment.

interventions.name: convencional treatment
interventions.description: is a physiotherapy treatment for neurological patients

primaryOutcomes.description: measures of gait motor ability using the time up ang go test.
measurements of spatiality using the modified Ashworth scale

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* left middle cerebral artery infarction
* impaired stability during walking
* patient between the age range 18 to 70 years old

Exclusion Criteria:

* patient under 18 years of age
* patients over 70 years of age
* undiagnosed left middle cerebral artery infarction patients
